title: Special edition, Monday, 5th February, 2018
bodyHTML:
8:18 pm
AS8:18pm

Hello everyone. Anything happening in markets?

Hinkley Wheeeeeeee
AS8:19pm

hi Hinkley, we've decided to start up an emergency edition of ML

AAAA Bonsoir !
BE8:20pm

Tinhat

Joseph Cotterill, FT ARE MY DOGECOIN OK
AAAA ça change !
8:20 pm
BE8:20pm

Awfully long time we've had to use the tin hat in earnest.

AS8:20pm

Must admit, I had been lulled into complacency by a VIX at like... 7

BE8:21pm

Well, 50 Cent's going to be happy.

8:21 pm
BE8:21pm

(The Vix one, not the other one.)

BE8:22pm

What's the damage currently, Alex?

kim BTC is also on a dive. Is that sentiment, or is there genuine contagion (through margin calls etc.)? My suspicion is the former, but......
AS8:22pm

Dow's down not quite 1000

8:22 pm
AS8:22pm

(apologies for the delay, we have one bloomberg and five markets reporters in this room)

AAAA just HODL
BE8:23pm

So, bounced off the 1600 point drop level recorded earlier.

BE8:23pm

That's something, I guess.

8:23 pm
AS8:23pm

yep, seems we've got ourselves a proper flash crash folks

BE8:23pm

Any sense of, "why now?"

AS8:24pm

well the Eagles won

8:24 pm
AS8:24pm

and also we do have the Bitcoin crash happening

TheTaffer by 50 Cent don't you mean Ruffer? ; )
AS8:25pm

just heard from a trader who said he hasn't heard anything significant or bearish from his institutional clients

BE8:25pm

It could be argued that the BTC crash was the canary in this particular coalmine, I guess. It went first.

8:25 pm
AS8:26pm

and we should remember BTC isn't entirely retail -- some very big prop-trading names are involved in that market

AS8:26pm

notably DRW ( https://www.wsj.co...ul-dead-1511787600 )

Phil Wheeeeee...
kim UST? I have neither 5 reporters nor a B'berg. Are all assets being hit?
BE8:27pm

CME's launch of BTC futures can perhaps be seen as the start of this chapter in Bitcoin's odd existence, which is now drawing to a close.

Phil Can’t believe BTC trading is big enough to seriously impact the DJIA, surely? That seems nuts. (But then everything about crypto is nuts, so...)
8:28 pm
BE8:28pm

But anyway, I guess there are bigger questions to tackle than crypto nonsense.

AS8:28pm

kim, Treasury yields appear to be down, which casts some doubts on the standard risk-parity unwind story

sour I don't think BTC could have caused this, it's way too small...right?
BE8:29pm

So what of Jerome Powell? This kind of tumble does make his first day rather trickier.

Phil Stocks down, bonds down => markets suddenly fear significant inflation? How are TIPS doing?
kim Thanks, AS.
Kadhim Shubber FT Just to note that this has happened on literally the first trading day without Yellen in the chair
8:29 pm
AS8:29pm

well something bizarre happened with US stocks -- looks flash crash-y, or like someone got blown out of some position

Obruni 10 yr is at 2.768%
Kadhim Shubber FT Nice send off if you can get it
BE8:30pm

Any theories yet about interest rates changing their incline? That's usually the first support mechanism to come into play on days like this.

AS8:30pm

Bryce -- entertainingly the US stock market is a major factor in some Fed measures of financial conditions

Matthew C Klein FT On the bright side, this will help modestly tighten financial conditions from what had been extremely loose levels...
8:31 pm
AS8:31pm

so financial conditions at the end of today will be tighter than yesterday -- and they take that sort of thing into account making policy

AS8:32pm

(yep for better or worse matt)

Twopennyworth I went to the bathroom for less than a minute and came back to find I had been stopped out of 90% of my long position on IG. Multiply that by however many tens of thousands of users and you can see why flash crashes happen (NB margin debt at record high)
KS8:33pm

Nice for the markets to give Powell such a friendly welcome

8:32 pm
KS8:33pm

(hi)

KS8:33pm

As someone who has basically no functioning memory of pre-2008... is the bull market over?

AS8:34pm

hi kadhim! separately I've heard options market-makers are having a pretty solid day

8:34 pm
AS8:34pm

as in, spreads are wide and people are actually paying them

AS8:35pm

and tbh no idea about the End of the Bull Market (TM) now that we're off the lows

BE8:36pm

(@Commenters: apologies if you're stuck in "pending". At this time of day our moderation team is less of a team and more like one bloke called Phil. We'll get to you.)

Blake How about stocks and bonds are supremely overvalued and market now exhausted? Hence sudden major declines likely!
8:37 pm
KS8:37pm

If this was a turning point, it would ironically come at a point of supreme confidence

KS8:37pm

From Factset:

KS8:37pm

In fact, the first quarter of 2018 marked the largest increase in the bottom-up EPS estimate over the first month of a quarter since FactSet began tracking the quarterly bottom-up EPS estimate in Q2 2002. The previous record for the largest increase in the bottom-up EPS estimate was 3.5%, which occurred during the first month (April) of Q2 2010.

Chris Bring back Yellen!
8:38 pm
BE8:38pm

This is a point we made here last week. https://ftalphavil...tslive/2018-01-26/

AS8:38pm

Yep, and earnings growth is actually accelerating

Obruni Even with the recent price drop, Dogecoin is still up over 1600% in the past year (Bitcoin is just under 600%). Who would have thought that it would have been a better investment than Bitcoin?
AS8:39pm

But at risk of stating the obvious, that did... not seem like a fundamental selloff

Phil I am not that bloke called Phil btw, so don’t blame me if you get moderated :)
8:40 pm
AS8:40pm

which is why I'm willing to consider to the idea that some weird unwinding of a levered Bitcoin trade could've played a role here

AS8:41pm

along with other levered SPY retail trades

Phil AS: it seems incredible to me that any large player would have been dumb enough to pile into cryptocurrencies on margin. But stranger things have happened...
ddle fat fingers?
KS8:41pm

I can't get my head around the idea that a bitcoin trade would be big enough to send all three US stock indexes down

8:41 pm
KS8:42pm

(that's my polite way of saying: lol cmon no way)

AS8:42pm

well no, not a bitcoin trade necessarily

ddle lol @ dogecoin
Phil ddle. Tape is looking a bit flash-crashy I agree.
AS8:43pm

but these types of things are bizarre in that (besides fat fingers) it's often impossible to pick out one catalyst

8:43 pm
KS8:43pm

Looks like S&P is recovering a bit from its low now, though Nasdaq is tipping back over again

ddle macro fund calling the end of globalisation due to trump and brexit?
Rhomboid This just looks like a bunch of momentum trading strategies all reversing positions at the same time..which was always going to be messy🙄
AS8:44pm

usually they happen when positioning is so extreme/out of whack that it's like a dam breaking (lots of pressure, then a few extra things make the whole thing fall down)

Obruni "Phil's fat fingers" would be a great name for an improvisational folk jazz band
AS8:44pm

(tough to say what specific thing did it)

8:45 pm
AS8:45pm

hmm what else can we say -- financials and energy are down most in the S&P 500

BE8:45pm

I'm going "crypto crash is coincidental and equity selloff is a correction not a crash." I'm also going with "this is the ruction on rising credit costs that we've talked about for about a decade."

arminius is this not market structure-or lack of-related?
Thud whats a ruction?
KS8:46pm

Just looking at Twitter, Patrick Chovenac reckons it's an inflation/interest rates thing

8:46 pm
KS8:46pm

https://twitter.com/prchovanec/status/960604180879740928

AS8:46pm

there are really two issues though, right?

AS8:47pm

the first is "why have stocks been going down for a few days"

8:48 pm
BE8:48pm

As a market reporter for 20 years, I'm going to go with "daily market moves nearly never have a catalyst."

AS8:48pm

the second is "why did the Dow puke that much that quickly"

KS8:49pm

As a [insert topic] reporter for three years, I"m going to leave this here and wink suggestively at it

bones30 https://www.zerohedge.com/news/2018-01-30/renaissance-warns-significant-correction-risk-prepares-turbulence-ahead
8:48 pm
KS8:49pm

https://twitter.com/TheStalwart/status/960613648082325504

KS8:50pm

Alex, I feel like the first question has to at least be partly answered by the sell off in bonds that's been going on for more than a few days now

AS8:50pm

yes that's the inflation/bonds story

Policy Tensor @KS its a classic risk-off. Of course all risk premia will expand together! One can almost hear Big Greenwich Money exiting BTC.
8:51 pm
AS8:51pm

but the action in Joe's chart? DJIA down almost 1600 points? that seems pretty obviously structural

BE8:51pm

(I bet lots of asset classes I'm sure bottomed out at that moment. from Intel to frozen orange juice futures.)

Obruni Can a similar price correction please happen in NYC real estate? Asking for a friend.
KS8:52pm

(yes, but bitcoin is meant to be uncorrelated)

kim @Obruni, tell him not to worry. America will be great again.
8:53 pm
BE8:53pm

(I can't for the life of me imagine why anyone would think it would be.)

KS8:54pm

(shall we stop whispering now?)

AS8:55pm

well the DJIA's down more than 1000 points again

8:56 pm
BE8:57pm

https://twitter.com/BCAppelbaum/status/960614104552689665

kim I'm not sure that just because BTC is irrational that it's uncorrelated with other risk assets. It's perhaps the best indicator that people have been buying stuff for fear of being left-out, and could now be more exposed to risk than they are used to being. Some in BTC, some in SPX, perhaps a few in both.
AS8:58pm

but apparently this selloff has legs? not 750-points-in-15-minutes type of legs

KS8:58pm

Does that make it more or less likely that this is a Proper Sell Off, or an Accident?

8:58 pm
AS8:59pm

so maybe you're right and the Bull Market Is Over(TM), Kadhim

AS8:59pm

why choose between the two?

Policy Tensor @kim, coins are a frontier asset class. They always respond more to the tide going out than AE risk assets.
KS8:59pm

President Trump's spokesperson disagrees

8:59 pm
KS8:59pm

Look, markets do fluctuate in the short term. We all know that. And they do that for number of reasons. But the fundamentals of this economy are very strong and they're headed in the right direction -- for the middle class, in particular

Max Loss Volatility forms the basis of most risk models, increase volatility and your position size has to be scaled back and of course you get margin called just for good measure. This has little to do with BTC and everything to do with going from a very low volatility environment to higher vol.
AS9:00pm

ha they're taking the populist approach I see

KS9:00pm

It would be interesting to see Trump handle a proper sell off in the markets

C. Sandlund @BE -- Brilliant!
9:00 pm
KS9:00pm

Given how much he's staked his reputation on the S&P going up and up and up

Policy Tensor @Max, I second that. Risk ~ vol*leverage
Max Loss P.S. anyone worked out why the Nasdaq fell in spring 2000, as I’m still trying to figure that out 18 years later...
AS9:01pm

only about half of Americans own stocks, per Gallup, and I'm guessing that group might not include the "middle class" they have in mind

GLA Not a proper crash until real estate falling...
AS9:02pm

Max good point -- we've been hearing for years that rising rates & shrinking QE are a transition into higher vol

9:02 pm
AS9:02pm

so maybe this is actually it?

Max Loss When credit goes then it moves from a market problem to a Chapter 11 and real economic problem
Policy Tensor In order to maintain a constant probability to default, a dealer must shrink her balance sheet. Risk-offs are often the result of shrinking balance sheet capacity. This is especially true of risk-offs that are not geopolitical or real macro in origin.
Policy Tensor And by shrink I mean grow less fast. Hahaha
KS9:03pm

That's the close right? S&P and Dow down over 1,000. Nasdaq down about 300

AS9:03pm

yep, that's the close

GLA Tax cuts now priced in so looking at fundamentals?
9:03 pm
AS9:03pm

Max that reminds me to check into how our old friend HYG is doing

BE9:04pm

Biggest points drop in history for the SPX I'm told.

bones30 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0akBdQa55b4 ?
BE9:04pm

Biggest since 2011 for Dow.

9:05 pm
AS9:05pm

and the worst percentage drop since August 2011 for the SPX

Policy Tensor @AS shrinking QE should generate higher vol if for no other reason than to compensate for the additional duration risk off-loaded onto market participants/intermediaries.
KS9:06pm

Have some Ray Dalio

KS9:06pm

What we are seeing is typical late-cycle behavior, though more exaggerated because the durations of investment assets (i.e., their sensitivities to interest rate changes) are greater.

9:06 pm
AS9:06pm

(by the way, the HYG ETF fell along with everything else, but recovered fairly well by the end of the day)

KS9:06pm

these big declines are just minor corrections in the scope of things, there is a lot of cash on the side to buy on the break, and what comes next will be most important. As shown, the recent price declines are not even noticeable within context of the bigger and longer term picture

KS9:07pm

Here's his whole post

9:06 pm
KS9:07pm

https://www.linked...-like-ray-dalio-1/

AS9:07pm

He's got a point -- everything does look pretty expensive

AS9:10pm

Policy, i'm less sure that risk-off is the result of that, but dealers do tend to trade more on an agency basis when this sort of thing happens (i.e. step back & stop internalizing)

58ap Futures a lot lower after the US close ?
9:10 pm
AS9:10pm

which is patently unhelpful for the rest of the market, but a perfectly reasonable thing for them to do!

KS9:11pm

Yeah, but he also talks about capacity constraints, and basically there's evidence for whatever side you want to take on that

KS9:11pm

Joe Lavorgna's note just out now:

9:11 pm
KS9:11pm

The capacity utilization rate measures slack in the
factory sector. When we have the latter, pricing
power tends to be weak. As shown in the nearby
chart, capacity utilization rate increased 0.7% to
77.9% in December, the highest reading since
February 2015. Yet, this is still below its postrecession
peak of 79.2% (November 2014) as well
as the highs reached in the two previous business
cycles: November 1997 (84.8%) and December
2007 (81.0%). With inflation still running under 2%,
it would seem prudent for the Powell-led Fed to
take a cautious approach with respect to removing
monetary accommodation.

kim There's a lot of cash on the side because the CBs have exchanged bonds for cash. I'm not sure that sort of cash is destined for equities.
Chris Didn't Dalio just say it feels dumb to hold cash at Davos?
KS9:12pm

The ISM data show a sharp increase
relative to the November 2015 cyclical low (43.1).
But, the current 59.8 reading is still well below its
February 2011 cyclical high (64.5). Moreover, the
ISM series is also well below the peaks seen in the
two previous business cycles, echoing the history
of the capacity utilization rate. Thus, it would be
wise for Fed tightening to proceed cautiously

AS9:16pm

e-mini futures at a new low for the March contract after the close

9:16 pm
BE9:16pm

And in terms of tomorrow's kickoff we have FTSE 100 futures at 7,069.8, off 3.6 per cent. Dax futures just holding off 12k, down 5.5 per cent.

BE9:17pm

Vix futures sticking above 33, up 117 per cent on the day.

AS9:17pm

Chris, I think those comments were about accelerating earnings growth (which is happening)

9:17 pm
KS9:18pm

(just to say, it's amazing to see trad finance types make the exact same arguments as crypto fanatics)

KS9:18pm

https://twitter.com/kairyssdal/status/960613110607433728

AS9:18pm

but as turns out, Larry Fink was urging everyone to invest too

9:18 pm
AS9:18pm

and I find that a bit more problematic, since he runs retail-oriented BlackRock & not an institutionally-focussed hedge fund

Policy Tensor Dalio is right but for the wrong reason. There is no evidence of any acceleration in inflation due to the economy hitting constraints. Investors are sitting on a lot of duration already and they are expected to absorb much more from central banks. This makes the market very jumpy with respect to variation in the expected path of rates. Inflation is likely to disappoint again; this tightening cycle is going to be shallow. So this is just going to prove a blip and not the return of reasonable valuations. I suspect that Dalio was holding risk, not cash today.
AS9:20pm

either way usually boils down to: "Get out of cash [and pay me fees]", says Area Fund Manager

Chris @Policy Tensor... so why is the FED still on a path to hike rates if inflation is not accelerating + evidence that there is more slack in the labor market?
AS9:22pm

anything else interesting in the inboxes, KS & BE?

9:23 pm
AS9:23pm

if not we'll call it a night with these comments from Torsten Slok:

KS9:23pm

Well, I've got a bunch of comments about how it's a healthy correction and please don't ask me to sell etc

KS9:23pm

So go ahead :)

9:23 pm
BE9:23pm

S&P futures at 2,607 vs a 2,648.99 close.

AS9:24pm

This it not the taper tantrum, this is the real thing

Following Friday’s wage data markets are coming to the conclusion that the US economy is close to overheating and therefore that the risks of inflation are bigger than the risks of a recession. Higher inflation risk means higher short and long rates. With valuations stretched in both equities and credit, risky assets are more vulnerable to higher interest rates than before. The allocation of money from risky assets to risk-free assets is going to be bumpy, as seen in markets today. Fundamentally, we expect such episodic bouts of turbulence, but the underlying economic expansion will continue.

AS9:24pm

(that above was from Slok from DB)

Bonnemort Doesn't feel anything like 2008 though.
9:24 pm
KS9:24pm

Slok doesn't know what's going on

KS9:24pm

This guy's got it

KS9:24pm

https://twitter.com/rcsanchez93/status/960607837352267778

9:24 pm
KS9:25pm

(Ok, I'm done)

KS9:25pm

(I'm going to go look after all of my investments now and by that I mean stare at Twitter until I'm forced to go to bed)

BE9:26pm

Thumbs up

9:26 pm
KS9:26pm

Thanks rabble on the right for joining us to discuss the (maybe) end of the bull market

AS9:26pm

Thanks for stopping by everyone

AS9:27pm

...see you on Twitter

9:27 pm
KS9:27pm

bye!
